profile_positions.description:
of the company: 
Maersk Ship management (MSM) Rotterdam is one of the main crewing centres within the Maersk group. They manage a fleet of about 65 container vessels and 3000 crew members. MSM carries out the technical maintenance for the ships, while for the seafarers it performs the crew planning, HR, payroll and finance.  

I was recruited by the director of Maersk Ship management to lead an IT project with a budget of 1.38 million USD, with the following main aims: 
To replace the old crew planning, HR and payroll office applications by a new integrated system. 
Arrange a data load from the existing applications. 
To implement the new system in 6 different locations worldwide.
Arrange interfaces to the payroll and finance systems.
Make sure users are prepared, trained and motivated.
To roll out a new on board system for crew planning, payroll, finance and HR on 35 vessels.  

Main achievements: 	The project was completed successfully, within budget and on time. The main benefits were improved efficiency, major data quality improvements and standardization within the Maersk group.
Personally, I got invaluable experience in the field of IT project management. 
I learned to do project planning, work flow and gap analysis, business process mapping and setting up user training sessions. On the technical side I was instrumental in dealing with matters like data loads and interface building. I had a leading role in the project board and was a member of the project executive board. The project was managed in line with the Prince2 rules.
profile_positions.title: Project manager

profile_positions.description:
I was recruited by the director operations region Europe (all European countries plus parts of the Middle East and North Africa) to enhance the role of container management in his team, improve communications with our overseas and head offices and overhaul the management reporting. 
In this role I was supervising 5 area managers in various countries and a small team of 3 within the department. 
My main tasks and responsibilities were: 
a) The planning and movement of empty containers 
b) Stock control and inventory management. 
c) Management reporting. 
d) Create the yearly budget and K.P.I. targets.
e) End responsibility for the maintenance & repair activities. 
The annual budget for the above mentioned activities was approximately 200 million US dollar. 

Main achievements: In this period we greatly improved our management reporting, the empty planning and stock control. Subsequently the trend line of the key performance indicators showed a more consistent and favourable trend. We initiated extra costs savings of 4 million USD annually by making better use of our transport methods, reducing the inventory and initiating new ideas and smart operations. As a result we managed to stay well within the financial budget every year.
profile_positions.title: General manager container management

profile_positions.description:
During this period I was in charge of a small project team which performed a study of the full and empty container flows within Europe.
Main achievements: 	The study resulted in a number of recommendations to our senior management committee about make or buy decisions related to inland container terminals and inland haulage activities. Shortly after our recommendations were presented, the first steps were taken to buy inland terminals and change routings and modes of transport for some of our container flows.
profile_positions.title: business development manager

profile_positions.description:
Manager allocation control, P&O Nedlloyd region Asia.  
I was in charge of a team which was managing the allocation of space on our vessels for our sales and marketing teams. Our team worked in a very busy and dynamic environment where we played a pivotal role between sales and marketing and various operational departments in the region. 
Main achievements: 	During this time I was able to significantly improve the buying and selling of space with other shipping lines, outside our alliance thereby improving the service to our customers and reducing costs for our company.
We improved our management reporting, giving our commercial department better information about the load factors of our vessels. 
We set up an interface with PSA in Singapore, which greatly improved our information about the transhipment activities in this area.
profile_positions.title: Manager Slot Capacity

profile_positions.description:
I was hired by the director of the region Australia/New Zealand to bring the operational activities and reporting more in line with the other areas. I was in charge of regional container management, operational procurement and operational cost control. 
Main achievements: 	I successfully managed to streamline and improve our reporting and working procedures bringing them in line with standard practice in the other regions and head offices. The end result was that operational management for Australia and New Zealand became part of the region Asia pacific.
profile_positions.title: General Manager Operations

profile_positions.description:
I was leading a team which was in charge of the management and control of the worldwide container fleet. As a result of the merger in January 1997 the central container management department of the new company was placed in Rotterdam. As a member of the ICM management team I coordinated the transition of activities for container planning, reporting and forecasting. I played a leading role in the set up of the container management teams in our 10 regional offices. 
Main achievements: 	The transition of activities was done very successfully, without disrupting any reporting lines or major operational problems. We quickly managed to create successful planning teams within the head office and regional offices. One of the main success factors was the fact that we were truly able to select the best working practice of both companies. This resulted in immediate efficiency improvements and very large synergy savings.
